content.title: Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) - Berlin Definition
content.summary: ARDS is a syndrome of acute hypoxemic respiratory failure characterized by bilateral pulmonary infiltrates not fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload. The Berlin Definition (2012) classifies severity by PaO2/FiO2 ratio on PEEP ≥5 cmH2O: mild (200-300), moderate (100-200), severe (<100).
key_points: Berlin Definition requires: acute onset (≤7 days), bilateral infiltrates, hypoxemia (P/F ≤300 on PEEP ≥5), non-cardiogenic
Severity classification: Mild P/F 200-300 (27% mortality); Moderate P/F 100-200 (32% mortality); Severe P/F <100 (45% mortality)
Low tidal volume ventilation (6 mL/kg IBW) with plateau pressure <30 cmH2O is cornerstone therapy
Prone positioning for severe ARDS (P/F <150) reduces mortality by ~16%
Conservative fluid management improves oxygenation and ventilator-free days
Common causes: pneumonia, sepsis, aspiration, trauma, pancreatitis, transfusion-related
content.statement: ARDS represents the severe end of acute lung injury spectrum with high mortality despite advances in supportive care. The Berlin Definition provides standardized criteria for diagnosis and severity stratification, enabling consistent enrollment in clinical trials and prognostication.

explanation.intuition: ARDS results from diffuse alveolar damage triggered by direct (pulmonary) or indirect (extrapulmonary) insults. The inflammatory response increases alveolar-capillary permeability, flooding alveoli with protein-rich edema fluid, inactivating surfactant, and causing alveolar collapse. This creates right-to-left shunt and refractory hypoxemia.
explanation.key_insight: The P/F ratio standardizes hypoxemia assessment and predicts mortality. However, it must be measured on adequate PEEP (≥5) to avoid underestimating severity. The PEEP requirement was added in Berlin Definition to address this limitation of the prior AECC definition.
explanation.technical_details: PaO2/FiO2 (P/F) ratio calculation: if PaO2 60 on FiO2 0.4 → P/F = 60/0.4 = 150 (moderate ARDS). For mild ARDS, CPAP ≥5 or HFNC is acceptable; moderate-severe requires invasive ventilation with PEEP ≥5.

definitions_glossary.ards: Acute respiratory distress syndrome: acute onset bilateral infiltrates with hypoxemia not explained by cardiac failure
definitions_glossary.berlin_definition: 2012 consensus definition replacing AECC criteria with severity stratification by P/F ratio
definitions_glossary.pao2_fio2_ratio: P/F ratio: arterial oxygen tension divided by fraction of inspired oxygen; measure of oxygenation efficiency
definitions_glossary.diffuse_alveolar_damage: Histopathologic correlate of ARDS with hyaline membranes, edema, and type I pneumocyte necrosis
definitions_glossary.exudative_phase: Early ARDS (days 1-7) with pulmonary edema and hyaline membrane formation
definitions_glossary.proliferative_phase: Intermediate ARDS (days 7-21) with type II pneumocyte hyperplasia and early fibrosis
definitions_glossary.fibrotic_phase: Late ARDS (>3 weeks) with extensive fibrosis in some patients
definitions_glossary.lung_protective_ventilation: Low tidal volume (6 mL/kg IBW), limited plateau pressure (<30), permissive hypercapnia strategy
definitions_glossary.positive_end_expiratory_pressure: PEEP prevents alveolar collapse, improves oxygenation, and redistributes edema
definitions_glossary.prone_positioning: Placing patient prone for 16+ hours improves V/Q matching and reduces mortality in severe ARDS
definitions_glossary.refractory_hypoxemia: Hypoxemia unresponsive to increasing FiO2 due to shunt physiology
definitions_glossary.driving_pressure: Plateau pressure minus PEEP; correlates with mortality; target <15 cmH2O

pathophysiology.mechanism: ARDS results from dysregulated inflammatory response causing diffuse alveolar damage. Neutrophil-mediated injury increases alveolar-capillary permeability, allowing protein-rich fluid into alveoli. Surfactant inactivation and alveolar collapse create dependent atelectasis. Pulmonary vasoconstriction increases dead space. The combination of shunt (perfused but unventilated alveoli) and dead space (ventilated but unperfused) impairs both oxygenation and CO2 elimination.
key_pathways: Initiating insult (sepsis, pneumonia, aspiration) → systemic inflammatory response
Neutrophil activation → release of proteases, ROS, cytokines
Endothelial and epithelial injury → increased permeability → pulmonary edema
V/Q mismatch and shunt → refractory hypoxemia
pathophysiology.clinical_significance: ARDS mortality remains 30-40% despite decades of research. Lung-protective ventilation is the only intervention with proven mortality benefit. Focus has shifted to preventing ventilator-induced lung injury.

berlin_definition_2012.timing: Acute onset within 1 week of known clinical insult or new/worsening respiratory symptoms
berlin_definition_2012.chest_imaging: Bilateral opacities not fully explained by effusions, lobar collapse, or nodules
berlin_definition_2012.origin_of_edema: Respiratory failure not fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload (echocardiography if no risk factor)

oxygenation.mild: P/F 200-300 mmHg with PEEP or CPAP ≥5 cmH2O

differential_diagnosis: Cardiogenic pulmonary edema (elevated PCWP, BNP, response to diuretics)

lung_protective_strategy.tidal_volume: 6 mL/kg ideal body weight (not actual weight)
lung_protective_strategy.peep: Titrate using ARDSNet PEEP/FiO2 tables or transpulmonary pressure
lung_protective_strategy.permissive_hypercapnia: Accept pH >7.20; prioritize lung protection over normocapnia

prone_positioning.indication: Severe ARDS (P/F <150) within 48 hours of onset
prone_positioning.protocol: 16+ hours per day prone; shown to reduce mortality (PROSEVA trial)
prone_positioning.mechanism: Improves V/Q matching, reduces dependent atelectasis, decreases VILI

neuromuscular_blockade.benefit: ROSE trial showed no mortality benefit; use selectively

conservative_fluid_management.target: CVP <4 or PAOP <8 after initial resuscitation
conservative_fluid_management.benefit: Improved oxygenation, more ventilator-free days (FACTT trial)

rescue_therapies.inhaled_pulmonary_vasodilators: Inhaled NO or epoprostenol for refractory hypoxemia; no mortality benefit
rescue_therapies.ecmo: VV-ECMO for severe refractory hypoxemia (P/F <80 for 6h or pH <7.20) after optimizing ventilation
rescue_therapies.corticosteroids: Dexamethasone in COVID ARDS (RECOVERY trial); controversial in non-COVID ARDS

skos.definition: A syndrome of acute onset bilateral pulmonary infiltrates with hypoxemia (P/F ≤300 on PEEP ≥5) not fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload

learning_objectives: Apply the Berlin Definition criteria to diagnose and classify ARDS severity
Calculate ideal body weight and set appropriate tidal volume (6 mL/kg IBW)
Explain the rationale for lung-protective ventilation strategies
Identify indications for prone positioning and its mortality benefit
Differentiate ARDS from cardiogenic pulmonary edema
clinical_pearls: Use IBW (not actual weight) for tidal volume: most common error in ARDS management
P/F ratio must be on PEEP ≥5; lower PEEP underestimates severity
Prone positioning for ≥16 hours reduces mortality by ~16% in severe ARDS (NNT 6)
Driving pressure (<15 cmH2O) may be better predictor of outcomes than Pplat alone
Echo to exclude cardiogenic edema if no clear ARDS risk factor identified
ARDS can develop within hours to 7 days of the precipitating insult
common_misconceptions: Use actual body weight for tidal volume (must use IBW)
Higher PEEP is always better (must individualize; excessive PEEP causes harm)
ARDS is a diagnosis of exclusion (it has specific Berlin criteria)
